column4: I am going insane here...can somebody please, please tell me how I can simply run two .sh scripts, one as my normal user and one as root, on startup in 12.04?
There are tons of explanations on the internet, but none of them work
I want at least one to start my VNC server (non-root) and at least one to mount a disk and perform some directory mounting trickery (root)
But I'll definitely expand them later on to start some screens with server programs and stuff like that
sesom42; I tried, it doesn't work
jrib; I've never managed to get any cron jobs (for other stuff) running correctly either. Same problem, tons of explanations and none work
And can fstab also mount folders?
jrib; you can also mount folders, as a symlink of sorts
you want to put a bind mount in your fstab?
the problem with tightvnc is that it resumably needs to wait for X11 to start. it might be better to create an upstart job that depends on lightdm
look at /etc/init/lightdm.conf or any other file in /etc/init. you can create a job that starts when lightdm.conf emits "login-session-start" and then starts tightvnc
anything in /etc will be run as root so /home/vdz is inappropriate
then you have to wait until you login to start tightvnc
my guess is that its not a problem to have the tightvnc server running as root
Darael; it finally works! Thank you so much
